description: From Middle English changen, chaungen, from Old French changier, from Late Latin cambiāre, from Latin cambīre, present active infinitive of cambiō (“exchange, barter”), from Gaulish cambion, *kambyom (“change”), from Proto-Celtic *kambos (“twisted, crooked”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ḱambos, *(s)kambos (“crooked”).

Cognate with Italian cambiare, Portuguese cambiar, Romanian schimba, Sicilian canciari, Spanish cambiar. Used in English since the 13th century. Displaced native Middle English wenden, from Old English wendan (“to turn, change”) (whence English wend).
The noun is from Middle English change, chaunge, from Old French change, from the verb changier. See also exchange. Possibly related from the same source is Old English gombe.

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) The process of becoming different.
(uncountable) Small denominations of money given in exchange for a larger denomination.
(countable) A replacement.
(uncountable) Balance of money returned from the sum paid after deducting the price of a purchase.
(uncountable) An amount of cash, usually in the form of coins, but sometimes inclusive of paper money.
(countable) A transfer between vehicles.
(baseball) A change-up pitch.
(campanology) Any order in which a number of bells are struck, other than that of the diatonic scale.
(Scotland, dated) A public house; an alehouse.
(countable, uncountable) The process of becoming different.
examples: The product is undergoing a change in order to improve it.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Small denominations of money given in exchange for a larger denomination.
examples: Can I get change for this $100 bill, please?

entries.meaning: (countable) A replacement.
(uncountable) Balance of money returned from the sum paid after deducting the price of a purchase.
examples: A customer who pays with a 10-pound note for a £9 item receives one pound in change.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) An amount of cash, usually in the form of coins, but sometimes inclusive of paper money.
examples: Do you have any change on you? I need to make a phone call.
This bus ride requires exact change.

entries.meaning: (countable) A transfer between vehicles.
examples: The train journey from Bristol to Nottingham includes a change at Birmingham.

entries.meaning: (baseball) A change-up pitch.
(campanology) Any order in which a number of bells are struck, other than that of the diatonic scale.
(Scotland, dated) A public house; an alehouse.
examples: They call an alehouse a change.

verbs.description: change (third-person singular simple present changes, present participle changing, simple past and past participle changed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become something different.
examples: The tadpole changed into a frog.   Stock prices are constantly changing.

entries.meaning: (transitive, ergative) To make something into something else.
examples: The fairy changed the frog into a prince.   I had to change the wording of the ad so it would fit.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To replace.
examples: Ask the janitor to come and change the lightbulb.   After a brisk walk, I washed up and changed my shirt.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To replace one's clothing.
examples: You can't go into the dressing room while she's changing.   The clowns changed into their costumes before the circus started.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To replace the clothing of (the one wearing it).
examples: It's your turn to change the baby.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To transfer to another vehicle (train, bus, etc.)
(archaic) To exchange.
examples: I would give any thing to change a word or two with this person.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To change hand while riding (a horse).
